question: What is the antidote to benzodiazepine poisoning?

A 38-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of double vision and unable to open the right eye completely. She has a history of a road traffic accident 4 months back. On examination of the right eye, there is eyelid drooping. The eye deviates outward and downward. Which cranial nerve is most likely damaged in this patient?
An 8-year-old child is brought to the clinic by his parents with the complaint of inattention and inability to sit in the class. What is the probable diagnosis?

A 39-year-old man presents to the emergency room with a traumatic spinal cord injury after a road traffic accident. Examination reveals spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. Which of the following benzodiazepines has the longest duration of action and is most suitable in this case?

A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after cutting his finger with a handsaw. There is a deep 2-cm long laceration on his right index finger. Bupivacaine is used as local anesthesia for suturing. What is the most common toxic adverse effect of bupivacaine?

A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency room with sudden urinary retention and lower limb weakness. The neurosurgeon is called, urgent surgery is recommended after relevant imaging studies. To establish a diagnosis of cauda equina syndrome, besides the aforementioned symptoms, what other clinical feature must be present?
Which of the following is true regarding acute viral encephalitis?

answers.option: Herpes RNA is detected by polymerase chain reaction (PCR)
Acyclovir 10 mg/kg 3 times daily for 2-3 weeks is given

question: What is the first-line treatment for trigeminal neuralgia?
A 33-year-old man undergoes surgery under general anesthesia. Which of the following anesthetic agents can sensitize the heart to the effects of catecholamines?

An unvaccinated, 18-month-old child is brought to the clinic with left lower limb weakness. His parents say that he had fever and diarrhea two days ago, which was managed with oral rehydration salts (ORS). Which of the following investigations is the most appropriate?
Which of the following agents is a weak anesthetic but a potent analgesic and thus is given with other inhalants?

A 50-year-old man presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with the complaint of a severe headache on the side of his head for the past 6 months. He also complains of vision loss in his left eye, blackouts, low-grade fever, and weight loss. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of high-grade fever and a headache for the last 20 days. He describes the headache as gradual in onset and moderate in intensity. In the last 10 days, he suffered three episodes of generalized seizures followed by weakness on the right side of the body. He was recently treated for a middle ear infection last month. He has a history of diabetes mellitus, controlled with metformin twice daily. On examination, his GCS is 15/15, right-sided power 2/5 in the upper and lower right limb, and speech is slurred. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A child requires multiple minor surgical procedures in the nasopharynx. Which drug has high surface local anesthetic activity and intrinsic vasoconstrictor actions that reduce bleeding in the mucous membrane?
Lorazepam can be safely used as a pre-anesthetic medication in a patient undergoing liver transplantation without the fear of excessive CNS depression. What is the reason for this?

answers.option: Actively secreted into the GI tract
A selective anxiolytic devoid of CNS depressant actions

question: A 47-year-old man with seizure disorder presents to his primary care physician for follow-up. Because of a recent exacerbation in his seizures, he has been prescribed lamotrigine. What is the most likely mechanism of action of this medication?

answers.option: Blockade of both sodium and calcium channels
Binds to collapsing response mediator protein-2

question: A 50-year-old male presents to the emergency room with a history of a road traffic accident with an altered level of consciousness and vomiting. The patient has abnormal flexion on pain, opens eyes on pain with no verbal response. Pupils are equal and reactive to pain stimuli. CT scan reveals a crescent hyper-density over the right frontoparietal region along with the midline shift. What is the GCS of this patient?

Mitochondrial dysfunction has been implicated as a contributing factor for Parkinson disease, that is caused by mutations in genes that encode the proteins DJ-1, PINK1, and parkin. What is the mode of inheritance?

answers.option: Autosomal dominant and X- linked recessive

question: A 19-year-old male is brought by his father to the psychiatry clinic with complaints of singing out loud throughout the night, sleeplessness, and claiming he is a famous singer. He had one similar episode in the past and one previous episode with symptoms of low energy and mood, for which he received treatment and reached a pre-morbid level of functionality. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old man has sustained multiple injuries in a road traffic accident and has to undergo emergency surgery for penetrating abdominal injury. The patient is given rapid sequence general anesthesia. Which neuromuscular blocking agent is given for rapid sequence induction?

A 78-year-old man with generalized anxiety disorder and mild dementia visits his primary care physician. Physical examination of the heart, lungs, and abdomen are unremarkable. Which of the following would be the best treatment option for his generalized anxiety disorder?

An elderly woman is about to undergo cardiothoracic surgery. If total intravenous anesthesia with fentanyl has been selected, then which of the following properties regarding fentanyl is the most appropriate one?

A 45-year-old woman on antiepileptic therapy complains of acne and increased facial hair growth. She is on no other medication. Which of the following most probable antiepileptic medication is responsible for the adverse effects this woman is experiencing?

A 45-year-old female presents to the outpatient clinic with a history of progressive difficulty in walking for 6 months along with numbness in hands and feet. On examination, she has a bilateral high stepping gait with a positive Romberg sign. There was wasting and weakness of distal muscles of both upper and lower limbs with reduced reflexes. What will be the first investigation of choice to diagnose the disease?

A 22-year-old female presents to the clinic in the 16th week of pregnancy for a routine check-up. Her doctor tells her that her baby has a neural tube defect. A deficiency of which of the following is cited as the most common cause of such defects?
What type of prevention is the administration of the polio vaccine as part of the expanded program on immunization (EPI)?
Which of the following is the most common presentation in multiple sclerosis (MS)?
Which scale is used to measure the extent of dementia?
What is the appearance of blood on computed tomography (CT) scan?

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the doctor by his parents with the complaint that he gets angry and frequently beats other children up at school. He also leaves school at times. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is a primary tumor of the brain that often presents with calcification?
Which lemniscus ends at the level of inferior colliculus?

A 16-year-old boy presents to the hospital with complaints of lower limb weakness, respiratory distress, and unilateral facial paralysis. On examination, deep tendon reflex is absent. The level of proteins in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is raised. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
What is Cushing's triad?
Which of the following occurs in Brown-Séquard syndrome?

answers.option: Contralateral loss of all sensation at level of lesion
Contralateral loss of pain, temperature, and crude touch above level of lesion
Ipsilateral loss of all sensation at level of lesion
Ipsilateral loss of all sensation below of lesion
Ipsilateral loss of pain, temperature, and crude touch below level of lesion

question: A 46-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with right-sided weakness in the whole body. He has complained of experiencing confused behavior and being unable to control his urine. What would be the investigation of choice in this case?
Albuminocytologic dissociation is seen in which of the following conditions?
Which of the following is seen in case of a skull fracture?

An 80-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his son and he complains that his father is unable to recognize family members and is experiencing hallucinations for the past six months. However, he can clearly recall older memories. What is the most probable diagnosis?
A 50-year-old man suddenly developed a generalized tonic-clonic seizure during a social gathering. What is most important regarding first aid?

answers.option: To avoid tongue fall or bite insert a spoon in the patient's mouth
His clothes should be loosened and glasses removed
Patient should be turned to his right side
No oral treatment should be given until complete consciousness is regained
Stay calm and observe the duration of the attack

question: A seizing patient should be immediately taken to the hospital in what situation?

answers.option: Seizure starts when they are asleep
Family history is positive for seizure disorder

question: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room after a sudden loss of consciousness with generalized stiffness in the body and jerking limbs. He is otherwise well but according to his parents, he is clumsy and drops objects in the morning 2-3 times per week, such as a toothbrush, teaspoon, breakfast plates, and cutlery. This has been going on for the last year. His paternal uncle is reported to have had epilepsy. What is the next best management plan?

answers.option: Suspect metabolic derangement and send blood for biochemical profile immediately
Cardiac arrhythmias should be ruled out first
EEG and MRI brain should be ordered
Observe; usually treatment is not indicated in a single seizure

question: A 70-year-old man is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of repeating phrases and questions, performing prayers at inappropriate times, and often incorrect use of vocabulary. His condition has been deteriorating for the last 2 years. What best describes his condition?

answers.option: This is part of normal aging
Inter-current illness, although common are not usually fatal
Cause may be hepatic or renal failure
Currently available treatment only delays progression
Genetics are more commonly involved in this etiology

question: A 43-year-old man, with history of chronic alcoholism, often in his drunk state would physically and verbally abuse family members. He becomes amnestic of his aggressive behavior but felt ashamed the next morning when informed of his misconduct. These events occurred repeatedly every few weeks. Why cannot these events be called dementia?

answers.option: Gender does not favor the diagnosis of dementia
Patient is normal between the events
Patient is under the influence of alcohol at the time of events

question: A 72-year-old man is brought to the neurology clinic by his son with the complaints of forgetting his way back home from the mosque multiple times in the past few months. What is a useful clinical scale to confirm a suspected cause of the mental decline?

A 16-year-old girl was brought to the emergency room with complaints of fever and vomiting for the last two days. At the time of presentation, she was observed to have sudden onset deviation of eyes to the right side, and twisting of the right hand followed by loss of consciousness for about one minute, along with generalized stiffness of the body. Another similar episode was observed while the patient was being examined, lasting one minute. How will you classify this seizure type?

answers.option: Generalized tonic-clonic seizure of non-motor type
Generalized tonic-clonic seizure of motor type
Focal onset seizure with impaired awareness

question: A 32-year-old lady presents to the emergency room with complaints of seizures for 3 hours, in the last two days she has had a high-grade fever with abnormal behavior and incoherent talk. On examination, there are no signs of meningeal irritation. Her blood glucose is 90 mg/dl. CT brain shows abnormal signals in both temporal lobes. Which of the following options most likely represents a cerebrospinal fluid detailed report for this patient?

answers.option: Protein 90 mg/dl, glucose 73 mg/dl, white blood cells 38/mm3, lymphocytes 80%
Protein 600 mg/dl, glucose 36 mg/dl, white blood cells 356/mm3, neutrophils 80%
Protein 39 mg/dl, glucose 79 mg/dl, white blood cells 2/mm3, lymphocytes 100%
Protein 246 mg/dl, glucose 70 mg/dl, white blood cells 3/mm3, lymphocytes 100%
Protein 800 mg/dl, glucose 24 mg/dl, white blood cells 498/mm3, lymphocytes 90%

question: Which of the following primary headaches is least commonly seen in neurology clinics?
What is the single most diagnostic bedside examination to rule out secondary malignant headache?

A 33-year-old female experienced recurrent attacks of loss of consciousness, almost every night before bedtime, variable in duration from 2 to 15 minutes, sometimes associated with jerking of the whole body and at other times total flaccidity. To differentiate between true seizures and non-epileptic psychogenic seizures, which is the best investigative modality?

A 30-year-old female, primigravida, a known case of migraine since her teenage, presents with a recurrence of her usual headaches at the 28th week of gestation after remaining dormant for the first two trimesters. NSAIDs should be avoided in her case to avoid the risk of causing which of the following problems?
What should be the initial investigation for stroke?

A 2-year-old baby is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of progressive lower limb weakness for the last five days. He has a history of viral sore throat ten days back. On examination, reflexes are absent in both lower limbs. The child is otherwise conscious and vitally stable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old baby is brought to the emergency room with complaints of fever on and off for the past 2 months, child has a history of cough along with fever. For 2 days, the child is drowsy and has multiple episodes of fits. According to the mother, the baby has lost weight in the last two months and the grandmother of the baby has a history of chronic cough. What is the most likely diagnosis?

An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room with complaints of high-grade fever, vomiting, and headache for the past one week. On examination, he is conscious but agitated, his temperature is 103 degrees Fahrenheit, his heart rate is 140 bpm, neck rigidity is present, and plantars are bilaterally upgoing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the appearance of a cerebral hemorrhage in comparison to normal cerebral parenchyma in acute phase?
A physical therapist wants to assess the balance of a 40-year-old Parkinson's patient. Which of the following scales would be appropriate for this purpose?

A 3-year-old girl is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of limping in her right leg. She has a history of fever, nausea, vomiting, and headaches that occurred two weeks ago. On examination, power, tone, and reflexes are all decreased on the right side. She is vaccinated. What is the most probable diagnosis?
The supporting cells of the nervous system are known as neuroglia. Different neuroglia has different functions. Which of the following neuroglia pairs is mismatched?

answers.option: Oligodendrocytes - myelin sheath in the central nervous system
Protoplasmic astrocytes - scarring cells of the central nervous system
Schwann cells - myelin sheath in the peripheral nervous system

question: Which of the following neuroglial cells are responsible for filling the gap after tissue injury?
At which level are the cell bodies of preganglionic parasympathetic fibers located in the lateral grey horn of the spinal cord?
What is the investigation for chronic ataxia?

The parents of a 7-year-old boy bring him to the clinic because of concerns about his recent behavior in school and at home. In the first grade, he is unable to sit still in class and moves and talks excessively. At home, he cannot sit still at the dining table and often interrupts his parents' conversations. What is the tentative diagnosis?

A 10-year-old boy is referred to a psychologist with complaints of extreme aggression towards his classmates, stealing others' belongings, manipulating his teachers and parents, and has also run away from school 2-3 times. What is the diagnosis in this boy?

For many months a 36-year-old man struggled silently. He dealt with a combination of work, family, and personal issues including the way he perceived himself. He developed anxiety and began cutting and scratching himself, punching, and hitting walls to cope with his emotional pain, intense anger, and frustration. What is the most likely behavior of this man?

answers.option: Solve his stresses by keeping his emotional wellbeing intact

question: A 54-year-old male who has a history of asthma complains of abdominal pain for 6 months and feels something is really wrong with him. He feels a mass in his abdomen. All investigations are normal, endoscopy is done twice and comes back normal. A CT scan of the abdomen is also normal. What is the diagnosis in this case?

A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after cutting his finger with a handsaw. There is a 2 cm long laceration on his right index finger. Bupivacaine is used as local anesthesia for suturing. What is the most likely toxicity bupivacaine can produce?

A 45-year-old woman on anti-epileptic medication complains of acne and increased hair growth. She is on no other medications. Which of the following is the most likely antiepileptic medication is causing the adverse effects described?

A 70-year-old man has a 2-day history of a worsening generalized headache and increasing obtundation. He now complains of stiffness in the neck. On physical examination, vital signs include a temperature of 38.7°C (101.6°F), a pulse of 85 beats/minute, a respiratory rate is 23 breaths/minute, and blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg. A complete blood count (CBC) reveals a white blood cell (WBC) count of 16, 850/microliter. Serum electrolytes include glucose of 88 mg/dl. A lumbar puncture yields cloudy cerebrospinal fluid with a glucose of 32 mg/dl, protein of 146 mg/dl, and cell count of 3800 WBCs (95% polymorphonuclear cells and 5% mononuclear cells) and 122 red blood cells (RBCs). He is started on antibiotic therapy. Which of the following long-term complications is most likely to develop from this man's current disease?

A patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of headache and blurred vision. He has a surgical history of sigmoid carcinoma. The doctor suspects that cancer has metastasized to the brain and requests an MRI brain scan for him. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication of MRI?

A 73-year-old man is undergoing a radical prostatectomy for prostatic adenocarcinoma. During this procedure, the anesthesiologist reports a drop in blood pressure with hypotension that persists for 30 minutes despite intervention with pressor agents. Which of the following pathologic lesions is most likely to occur in his brain as a consequence of this prolonged hypotensive episode?

answers.option: Linear parasagittal infarction of watershed area

question: A 40-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with the complaint of blurred vision and gait disturbance. Her brain MRI demonstrates high-signal intensity lesions involving a short segment of the spinal cord. Simultaneous brain MRI scans show multiple new and old lesions in periventricular, cortical, and subcortical regions. She has a history of a similar attack a few months back. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Each cellular component of the central nervous system responds differently to injury. Which of the following statements is correct about the pattern of injury in its respective cells?

answers.option: Neuronal injury commonly results in hyperplasia of neurons
Neuronal injury commonly results in their hypertrophy
Microglia undergo cell death by necrosis or apoptosis

question: A young man is brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state after running into a traffic accident. Which of the following will be the first-line radiological investigation in this patient?

answers.option: Plain CT scan of brain and spine
Plain x-rays of skull and spine

question: A 32-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of visual impairment and headache for three months. The examining medical student noted that the patient could not see in the temporal visual fields of both eyes. However, her visual acuity was normal. Which part of the optic pathway is involved in this patient?

A 65-year-old man is admitted to the medical intensive care unit for the treatment of pneumonia. On the 3rd day of admission, the patient suddenly develops bilateral hearing loss. There is no previous history of hearing impairment. Which drug is the likely offender in this case?

A 30-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with complaints of double vision and drooping of eyelids for one month. Upon questioning, she fatigues easily upon minimal exertion, and her symptoms worsen towards the end of the day. On examination, she has bilateral ptosis with external ophthalmoplegia and fatigable proximal limb muscles weakness. Reflexes and sensory examination are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

An 18-year-old boy presents to the outpatient department with a three-day history of progressive weakness of both the lower limbs. He has a history of diarrheal illness three weeks ago. On examination, he has decreased power in the lower limbs' proximal and distal muscles. Reflexes are absent all over. Sphincters are intact. Cerebrospinal fluid examination shows elevated proteins only. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old female, a typist by occupation, presents with pain and numbness in her right hand, mostly confined to the thumb, index, and middle fingers. Her sleep is also disturbed due to the pain. On examination, she had weakness in abduction and opposition of her right thumb and decreased sensation in lateral three and a half fingers. What is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.option: Radial neuropathy at the spinal groove

question: A 60-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of progressively increasing headaches for three months, difficulty walking, and urinary incontinence. Her CT scan of the brain shows dilated ventricles. What is the most likely diagnosis?
When studying neurons under a microscope from an H&E stained slide, some basophilic granules called the Nissl's substances were seen in the cytoplasm. Where are these granules located?
Which of the following cells with immune function arises from the embryonic mesoderm?
Which of the following lemniscus ends in the inferior colliculus of the mid-brain?
Which of the following is a major parasympathetic nucleus involved in the accommodation of the eye present in the midbrain?
What is the thin sheet of white matter that separates the lentiform nucleus from the claustrum in the basal nuclei?
According to the morphological classification, neurons are divided into different types. Which of the following is not a type of neuron based on this classification?
In which of the following sites is unipolar ganglia found?
Which of the following is the most common cause of dementia?

A brain tumor histopathology specimen shows cells with round nuclei with clear cytoplasm (fried egg appearance) associated with dystrophic calcification. What is the most likely brain tumor that exhibits these features?
A brain histopathology specimen shows pale substantia nigra and locus ceruleus with neuronal achromasia, tangles, and ballooned neurons. Which of the following diseases exhibits these features?
Which of the following risk factors is most commonly associated with patients requiring long-term treatment for depression?
A 10-year-old boy requires drug treatment for absence seizures. He has a past history of multiple generalized tonic-clonic seizures as well. Which of the following drugs is best suited in this case?
Which drug has the capacity to reverse the effects of opioids?
What is the most likely condition associated with a pattern of hypsarrhythmia on an electroencephalogram (EEG)?
A 31-year-old male patient requires local anesthesia for lower limb surgery. Which of the following local anesthetics is most likely to cause cardiotoxicity and arrhythmias?

A 68-year-old male patient requires pharmacological treatment for Parkinson disease. He has a past medical history of benign prostatic hyperplasia and chronic constipation. Which of the following drugs should not be used in this patient?
Which of the following is the most common primary brain tumor?

A 23-year-old male undergoes rapid sequence induction anesthesia for a life-saving surgery following a road traffic accident. During the procedure, he develops high-grade fever and generalized rigidity of the muscles. Which drug can be used to reverse this adverse outcome?
Which drug is suitable for the treatment of malignant hyperthermia?
Which of the following is a characteristic histopathologic finding in Parkinson disease?
Which of the following drugs works by increasing dopamine release, blocking cholinergic receptors, and inhibiting the N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptors?
Which of the following anti-depressants has a stronger risk of self-harm and suicide?
A 16-year-old female presents with complaints of experiencing seizures after awakening from sleep for 2 months. The seizures do not appear at any other specific time. What is the likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is true regarding the production of cerebrospinal fluid?

answers.option: Normal cerebrospinal fluid volume is 100 ml
It passes through lateral ventricle via aqueduct of sylvius
It enters subarachnoid space via two foramen of magendie
It is mainly produced by the ventricular wall
It is reabsorbed by the arachnoid granulations

question: A 22-year-old male swimmer presents in the emergency department with high-grade fever, headache, and neck stiffness. A provisional diagnosis of meningitis is made. What is the likely organism responsible for this presentation?
Which of the following is a common variable used for a pie chart?

A 33-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of recurrent headaches for 1 year. The headaches are constant in character and produce a tight band-like pain. The headache episode last for a few hours and relieves with pain killers. What is the likely diagnosis?
What is the mode of inheritance of Duchenne muscular dystrophy?

A 19-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with a complaint of muscle weakness for 8 months. After relevant examinations, the doctor ordered an evaluation of serum creatine kinase levels. The results show elevated levels of creatine kinase. What should be the next best step in the management of this patient?

A 44-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of mild fever for the past 3 months. The fever is associated with headaches, neck rigidity, malaise, and night sweats. His past medical history is significant for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. On physical examination, vital signs include a temperature of 38 °C (100.4°F), a pulse of 85 beats/minute, a respiratory rate is 23 breaths/minute, and blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg. Serum electrolytes include glucose of 88 mg/dl. A lumbar puncture yields cloudy cerebrospinal fluid with a glucose of 32 mg/dl, protein of 146 mg/dl, and cell count of 3800 WBCs with predominant mononuclear cells, and a positive acid-fast bacillus (AFB) stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 16-year-old girl is brought by her mother to the psychiatry clinic with concerns regarding her behavior for 2 weeks. She has stopped going to school and stays in her room the entire day. She refuses to eat food and claims that it has been poisoned. She also believes that her family has installed cameras in her room to keep a close eye on her. She has stopped interacting with her friends and family. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 41-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with worsening weakness in his right lower limb for the past three months. He also experiences extreme fatigue and pain in his limb. He has a medical history of a diagnosis of poliomyelitis at the age of 5 years which involved flaccid paralysis of the right lower limb that improved over a period of time. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient?

A 35-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of rigidity of his limbs for the past 2 weeks. He finds it difficult to initiate movements and when he tries to walk it feels as if he is shuffling along. His past medical history includes a diagnosis of schizophreniform disorder three months ago. He is currently taking depot injections of haloperidol for his treatment. What is the likely diagnosis?
A patient has been diagnosed with a motor neuron-related problem. Which of the following findings will lead to a revision of the diagnosis?

A 45-year-old female presents to the outpatient clinic with a complaint of anosmia for 5 months. Radiological imaging shows a mass in the anterior cranial fossa along the olfactory groove. A primary brain tumor is suspected. What is the cell of origin of the most likely tumor?
Which of the following is appropriate regarding histopathological features of multiple sclerosis?

answers.option: Perivascular lymphocytes with demyelination in white matter
Periventricular lymphoid aggregates with CD19 cells

question: Which type of cells are affected in poliomyelitis?

answers.option: Anterior horn cells of spinal cord

question: A 23-year-old patient presents with loss of proprioception and two-point discrimination on the right side of the body. Which structure is most likely severed in this case?

A 35-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with difficulty in using his right hand with pain for 4 months. He also experiences paresthesias and numbness in the hand. On examination, the pain is reproduced on tapping the volar aspect of the wrist reflex hammer. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient clinic by his mother with complaints of muscle weakness and clumsiness. He started walking at the age of 3 years. His gait remains unstable and he experiences frequent falls. On examination, when asked to stand up from a sitting position on the floor, the child assumes the hands-and-knees position and then climbs to a stand by walking his hands progressively up his shins, knees, and thighs. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after sustaining a bullet injury on his back. After initial resuscitation, a complete head-to-toe examination is performed. On examination, the patient has loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of his body. Which structure is damaged in this case?
Which among the following is/are biological symptoms of depression?

A 60-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with generalized weakness, pain in his limbs, and weight loss for 3 months. On examination, deep tendon reflexes are diminished. He has a 20-pack-year history of smoking. What is the likely diagnosis based on clinical suspicion?
Chlorpromazine is a typical antipsychotic drug. Which of the following receptors is not targeted by this drug?

A 30-year-old female presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of recurrent headaches and visual disturbances for 1 month. She is currently taking retinoid derivatives for the treatment of acne. Her body mass index (BMI) is 32 kg/m². On examination, fundoscopy reveals papilledema. What is the likely diagnosis?
Which of the following are signs and symptoms of raised intracranial pressure?

A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with weakness in his upper and lower limbs after falling from a height. The weakness is more in the upper limbs than the lower limbs. Which type of spinal cord injury is most likely responsible for this presentation?
What is the appropriate description for relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis?

answers.option: Frequent acute attacks and no recovery

question: A 19-year-old male presents with multiple cutaneous macules, nodules of the iris, and a brain mass detected by a previous computed tomography scan. Recently, a computed tomography scan revealed an adrenal mass which prompted a visit to the consultant neurologist. What is the likely diagnosis based on these findings?
Which of the following tumors crosses the cerebral hemispheres?
Which of the following is appropriate regarding motor neuron disease?

answers.option: Riluzole has small effect in increasing life expectancy up to 2 months
Disease is curative in early stage

question: A 50-year-old male presents to the clinic with proptosis and a black necrotic mass present in the nasal cavity. What is the likely diagnosis?
Which of the following common causes of coma does not involve focal neurologic deficits?

The first mutations identified as a cause of Parkinson disease involved SNCA, a gene that encodes α-synuclein, an abundant lipid-binding protein normally localized to synapses. This protein is a major component of the Lewy body, which is the diagnostic hallmark of Parkinson disease. What is the mode of inheritance of this mutation?
A student is performing a neurological examination of a patient with positive lower motor neuron lesion findings. Which of the following finding will be seen in the patient?

A 66-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with difficulty in getting up from his chair and buttoning his shirt for the past 3 months. On examination, no neurological deficits were noticed. What is the likely diagnosis?
A professor of epidemiology advises his students to take extreme care to avoid bias while taking a sample from the population. Which of the following is the more biased sampling technique?

A 45-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after experiencing a sudden "thunderclap" headache. The doctor ordered an urgent computed tomography scan and the results are inconclusive. What should be the next best investigation?
A patient is asked to protrude the tongue during a cranial nerve examination. It is observed that the tongue is deviated towards the right side. What is the cause of this finding?
